<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 265, 230, 280]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 289, 232, 304]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 265, 866, 280]]<|/det|>
9709/41  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 290, 866, 304]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[725, 314, 866, 329]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 378, 355]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 365, 371, 380]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 397, 214, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 413, 841, 617]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 648, 207, 663]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 663, 697, 694]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 72, 87, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 120]]<|/det|>
A winch operates by means of a force applied by a rope. The winch is used to pull a load of mass \(50\mathrm{kg}\) up a line of greatest slope of a plane inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The winch pulls the load a distance of \(5\mathrm{m}\) up the plane at constant speed. There is a constant resistance to motion of \(100\mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 129, 369, 147]]<|/det|>
Find the work done by the winch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 129, 875, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 71, 89, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 78, 635, 274]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 291, 876, 370]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) have masses \(m \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, where \(m > 0.1\). The particles are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a fixed smooth pulley and the particles hang vertically below it. Both particles are at a height of \(0.9 \mathrm{m}\) above horizontal ground (see diagram). The system is released from rest, and while both particles are in motion the tension in the string is \(1.5 \mathrm{N}\). Particle \(B\) does not reach the pulley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 380, 141, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 213, 397]]<|/det|>
Find \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 380, 875, 397]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 670, 136, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 670, 504, 688]]<|/det|>
Find the speed at which \(A\) reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 670, 875, 688]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 89, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 120]]<|/det|>
Three particles \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\), of masses \(0.1 \mathrm{kg}\), \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.5 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are at rest in a straight line on a smooth horizontal plane. Particle \(P\) is projected towards \(Q\) at a speed of \(5 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\). After \(P\) and \(Q\) collide, \(P\) rebounds with speed \(1 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 131, 139, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 599, 149]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(Q\) immediately after the collision with \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 131, 875, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 165, 875, 183]]<|/det|>
<form>Q now collides with \(R\). Immediately after the collision with \(Q\), \(R\) begins to move with speed \(V \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 490, 123, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 490, 875, 508]]<|/det|>
Given that there is no subsequent collision between \(P\) and \(Q\), find the greatest possible value

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 175, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>of</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 536, 875, 552]]<|/det|>
V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 533, 875, 552]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 72, 89, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 71, 875, 103]]<|/det|>
Two cyclists, Isabella and Maria, are having a race. They both travel along a straight road with constant acceleration, starting from rest at point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 115, 875, 147]]<|/det|>
Isabella accelerates for 5 s at a constant rate \(a \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\). She then travels at the constant speed she has reached for 10 s, before decelerating to rest at a constant rate over a period of 5 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 161, 875, 207]]<|/det|>
Maria accelerates at a constant rate, reaching a speed of \(5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) in a distance of \(27.5 \mathrm{~m}\). She then maintains this speed for a period of \(10 \mathrm{~s}\), before decelerating to rest at a constant rate over a period of \(5 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 220, 139, 237]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 220, 551, 237]]<|/det|>
Given that \(a = 1.1\), find which cyclist travels further.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 220, 875, 237]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 640, 176, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 640, 685, 657]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\) for which the two cyclists travel the same distance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 640, 875, 657]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 141, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 71, 875, 103]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the sloping section of the slide is rough and that the child comes to rest on the slide \(1.05 \text{m}\) after she reaches the horizontal section.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 114, 785, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between the child and the sloping section of the slide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 114, 876, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 72, 541, 87]]<|/det|>
